Vertical farming: In a world without farming, vertical farming could be a solution to feeding yourself and your family. Vertical farming is a method of growing plants in vertically stacked layers, often in indoor environments. This technique can increase crop yields while minimizing land use, making it a more efficient way to produce food. By setting up a vertical farm in your home or community, you could grow a variety of fruits, vegetables, and herbs, providing a reliable source of fresh produce for your family.

Aquaponics: Aquaponics is a sustainable food production system that combines aquaculture (raising fish and other aquatic animals) with hydroponics (growing plants in water). In a world without farming, aquaponics could be a great way to produce protein-rich foods like fish, as well as a variety of vegetables. By setting up an aquaponics system in your home or community, you could grow a sustainable and diverse food supply, while also providing a source of income through the sale of excess produce.

Urban beekeeping: In a world without farming, bees could play a crucial role in pollinating wildflowers and other plants, helping to maintain biodiversity. By setting up an urban beekeeping operation in your community, you could harvest honey and other bee products, while also providing a safe haven for bees to thrive. This could help to ensure the long-term health of the environment and the food supply.

Foraging and wildcrafting: In a world without farming, foraging and wildcrafting could become a vital means of obtaining food and other essential resources. By learning which wild plants are safe to eat and how to identify them, you could forage for wild edibles like berries, nuts, and greens. You could also learn how to wildcraft herbs and other plants for medicinal uses. By developing these skills, you could provide a reliable source of food and medicine for yourself and your family.

Community gardens: In a world without farming, community gardens could become a vital source of fresh produce for many people. By setting up a community garden in your neighborhood or town, you could provide a shared space for people to grow their own fruits, vegetables, and herbs.
